Module com.ning.breakout
Package com.ning.breakout.view

Class GameBoardManager

java.lang.Object
com.ning.breakout.view.GameBoardManager
public class GameBoardManager extends Object
GameBoardManager is the class which takes the responsibility of controlling some game objects (ball, paddle and bricks) and store the status info of the game.
Author:
Ning ZHU - modified
See Also:
  • Ball
  • Paddle
  • Brick

  • Constructor Details

    • GameBoardManager

      public GameBoardManager(javafx.scene.shape.Rectangle drawArea, int brickCount, int lineCount, double brickDimensionRatio, javafx.geometry.Point2D ballPos)
      The class constructor specifies the boundary of the game board, creates game objects and initializes the game status info. 
       
  Modified from the original source code:
  public Wall(Rectangle drawArea, int brickCount, int lineCount,
  double brickDimensionRatio, Point ballPos){

      this.startPoint = new Point(ballPos);

      levels = makeLevels(drawArea,brickCount,lineCount,
                                                  brickDimensionRatio);
      level = 0;

      ballCount = 3;
      ballLost = false;

      rnd = new Random();

      makeBall(ballPos);
      int speedX,speedY;
      do{
          speedX = rnd.nextInt(5) - 2;
      }while(speedX == 0);
      do{
         speedY = -rnd.nextInt(3);
      }while(speedY == 0);

      ball.setSpeed(speedX,speedY);

      player = new Paddle((Point) ballPos.clone(),150,10, drawArea);

      area = drawArea;
  }
      Parameters:
      drawArea - the boundary of the game board
      brickCount - the number of bricks in a level
      lineCount - the number of brick rows (lines) in a level
      brickDimensionRatio - the ratio of the width and height of the brick
      ballPos - the initial position of ball and paddle
      See Also:
      • Ball(BallModel, Group)
      • Paddle(PaddleModel, Rectangle, Group)
      • Brick
      • BrickFactory.makeLevel(int, Rectangle)

    • handleImpacts

      public void handleImpacts()
      Finds and handles the impact.

      Notices that when ball impacts the border (left or right boundary of the game board), the ball also can impact the paddle or brick at the same time.

      When the speed of the ball is too fast (changed by using the debug console), misjudgment may occur. 

       
  Modified from the original source code:
  public void findImpacts(){
      if(player.impact(ball)){
          ball.reverseY();
      }
      else if(impactWall()){
          brickCount--;
      }
      else if(impactBorder()) {
          ball.reverseX();
      }
      else if(ball.getPosition().getY() < area.getY()){
          ball.reverseY();
      }
      else if(ball.getPosition().getY() > area.getY() + area.getHeight()){
          ballCount--;
          ballLost = true;
      }
  }
      See Also:
      • Ball

    • isLevelPassed

      public boolean isLevelPassed()
      Returns:
      true if user break all bricks in the current level

    • resetBall

      public void resetBall()
      Moves the ball and paddle to the start point, resets the speed of ball and sets the lost status of the ball to false. 
       
  Modified from the original source code:
  public void ballReset(){
      player.moveTo(startPoint);
      ball.moveTo(startPoint);
      int speedX,speedY;
      do{
          speedX = rnd.nextInt(5) - 2;
      }while(speedX == 0);
      do{
          speedY = -rnd.nextInt(3);
      }while(speedY == 0);

      ball.setSpeed(speedX,speedY);
      ballLost = false;
  }

    • resetBricks

      public void resetBricks()
      Repairs all bricks and updates the brick count. 
       
  Modified from the original source code:
  public void wallReset(){
      for(Brick b : bricks)
          b.repair();
      brickCount = bricks.length;
      ballCount = 3;
  }
      See Also:
      • Brick.repair()

    • resetBallCount

      public void resetBallCount()
      Resets the ball count of the game board.

    • nextLevel

      public void nextLevel()
      Sets the game to the next level. 
       
  Modified from the original source code:
  public void nextLevel(){
      bricks = levels[level++];
      this.brickCount = bricks.length;
  }
